The reason the late President Kibaki came into an agreement with EABL to produce keg alcohol was to discourage illicit brews that are cheap. Making alcohol expensive only encourage consumption of illicit brews.

A small lesson in excise duty. Keg is basically tax free. It is made by EABL from sorghum and millet. Bottled beer is made from barley. It is sold in kegs not bottles to ensure it is sold in bulk. Most of the money gained from keg is channelled to farmers of sorghum and millet
Yes kuna fake makali mob, but EABL please msifute hao ma QC wa keg,

Next @CocaColaAfrica should be pushed to do it's sugar processing here. EABL should go beyond using sorghum for Keg and move into serious barley farming for its beers.
Just remove the high taxes from genuine alcohol, the illicit will lose market and EABL will pay highest corporate tax from sales. That was the idea of introduction of keg.

Breaking News: KRA is now demanding, EABL for a staggering Ksh 8.2 billion. In order to set up the Senator Keg facility and produce affordable beer to protect the general public from illegal alcohol, EABL received a waiver from the GoK in 2004.   KRA has now reviewed this waiver.

The Kenya Revenue Authority (KRA) is revisiting the tax waiver @EABL_PLC got in 2004 to enable them to set up the Senator Keg Plant & produce the low cost beer to save masses from illicit alcohol in Central ,. etc. KRA is demanding a whole Ksh 8.2bn from EABL. Khabusie!
